qas.question: What two types of organisms have remarkable differences in their genomic composition?
What type of organizing can be observed in eukaryote genomes?
In what types of eukaryotes is there a large amount of non-coding DNA?
What should you distinguish between when talking about gene coding?
How much of the genome is non-repetitive DNA in eukaryotes?
What is a major part of contents structure made of in non-coding regions?
What organization feature do prokaryotes have?
What area do mammals and plants have differences in?

context: When talking about genome composition, one should distinguish between <a0_0><b3_0>prokaryotes and eukaryotes<b3_0/><a0_0/> as the big differences on <b7_0>contents structure<b7_0/> they have. In prokaryotes, most of the genome <b4_0>(85–90%)<b4_0/> is non-repetitive DNA, which means coding DNA mainly forms it, while non-coding regions only take a small part. On the contrary, eukaryotes have the feature of <a1_0><b6_0>exon-intron<b6_0/><a1_0/> organization of protein coding genes; the variation of repetitive DNA content in eukaryotes is also extremely high. In <a2_0>mammals and plants<a2_0/>, the major part of the genome is composed of <b5_0>repetitive DNA<b5_0/>.
